cluster.display: When conducting a hypothesis test for a population __________, we use a z-test.
When conducting a hypothesis test for a population proportion, we use a __________.
When conducting a hypothesis test for a population __________, the variable is categorical.
When conducting a hypothesis test for a population proportion, the variable is __________.
The value proposed in the __________ hypothesis of a hypothesis test is called the __________ value.
The value proposed in the null __________ of a __________ test is called the null value.
The __________ proposed in the null hypothesis of a hypothesis test is called the null __________.
If our __________ is two-sided, we are looking for a difference from the null value in either direction.
If our alternative hypothesis is __________, we are looking for a difference from the null value in either direction.
If our alternative hypothesis is two-sided, we are looking for a __________ from the null value in either direction.
If our alternative hypothesis is two-sided, we are looking for a difference from the __________ in either direction.
When a __________ is random, it ensures that it is representative of the entire population.
When a sample is __________, it ensures that it is representative of the entire population.
When a sample is random, it ensures that it is representative of the entire __________.
In __________, the test statistic is a measure of how far the sample proportion or mean is from the null value.
In hypothesis testing, the __________is a measure of how far the sample proportion or mean is from the null value.
In hypothesis testing, the test statistic is a measure of how far the sample proportion or mean is from the __________.
In a __________ for the population proportion, the test statistic measures the difference between P̂ and p<sub>0</sub> in standard deviations .
In a z-test for the population proportion, the __________ measures the difference between P̂ and p<sub>0</sub> in standard deviations .
In a z-test for the population proportion, the test statistic measures the difference between P̂ and p<sub>0</sub> in __________ .
We can also say that the __________ is a measure of evidence against the null hypothesis H<sub>0</sub>.
We can also say that the test statistic is a measure of __________ against the null hypothesis H<sub>0</sub>.
We can also say that the test statistic is a measure of evidence __________ the null hypothesis H<sub>0</sub>.
We can also say that the test statistic is a measure of evidence against the __________ hypothesis H<sub>0</sub>.
The __________ test statistic we calculate, the more evidence we have against H<sub>0</sub>.
The larger __________ we calculate, the more evidence we have against H<sub>0</sub>.
The larger test statistic we calculate, the __________ evidence we have against H<sub>0</sub>.
The larger test statistic we calculate, the more __________ we have against H<sub>0</sub>.
Assuming that H<sub>0</sub> is true, the __________ is the probability of observing a test statistic as extreme or more extreme as that observed.
Assuming that H<sub>0</sub> is true, the p-value is the probability of observing a __________ as extreme or more extreme as that observed.
In a two-tailed or two-sided hypothesis test, the __________ will be twice as large as that of a one-sided test.
In a two-tailed or two-sided hypothesis test, the p-value will be __________ as large as that of a one-sided test.
In a two-tailed or two-sided hypothesis test, the p-value will be twice as __________ as that of a one-sided test.
In a two-tailed or two-sided hypothesis test, the p-value will be twice as large as that of a __________ test.
__________ correspond to areas and probabilities under the standard normal curve.
P-values correspond to __________ and probabilities under the standard normal curve.
P-values correspond to areas and __________ under the standard normal curve.
P-values correspond to areas and probabilities under the standard __________.
With a __________ sample size in a hypothesis test, we can expect a smaller margin of error and a narrower confidence interval.
With a larger __________ in a hypothesis test, we can expect a smaller margin of error and a narrower confidence interval.
With a larger sample size in a hypothesis test, we can expect a smaller __________ and a narrower confidence interval.
With a larger sample size in a hypothesis test, we can expect a smaller margin of error and a __________ confidence interval.
With a larger sample size in a hypothesis test, we can expect a smaller margin of error and a narrower __________.
If a hypothesis test is __________, we can also use a 95% confidence interval to reach a conclusion.
If a hypothesis test is two-sided, we can also use a __________% confidence interval to reach a conclusion.
If a hypothesis test is two-sided, we can also use a 95% __________ to reach a conclusion.
As the __________ of a hypothesis test increases, the results become more statistically significant.
As the sample size of a hypothesis test __________, the results become more statistically significant.
As the sample size of a hypothesis test increases, the results become more __________.
When hypothesis testing for the population __________ μ, we will use a t-test when σ is unknown.
When hypothesis testing for the population mean μ, we will use a __________ when σ is unknown.
When hypothesis testing for the population mean μ, we will use a t-test when σ is __________.
When hypothesis testing for the population __________ μ, we will use a z-test when σ is known.
When hypothesis testing for the population mean μ, we will use a __________ when σ is known.
When hypothesis testing for the population mean μ, we will use a z-test when σ is __________.
In a __________ for μ, the test statistic is a z-score of x̄ that tells us how far x̄ is from μ<sub>0</sub> in standard deviations.
In a z-test for μ, the test statistic is a __________ of x̄ that tells us how far x̄ is from μ<sub>0</sub> in standard deviations.
In a z-test for μ, the test statistic is a z-score of x̄ that tells us how far x̄ is from μ<sub>0</sub> in __________.
When σ is __________, we conduct a t-test and substitute s for σ.
When σ is unknown, we conduct a __________ and substitute s for σ.
When σ is unknown, we conduct a t-test and substitute __________ for σ.
A __________ differs from the standard normal distribution because it has more area in the tails of the curve.
A t-distribution differs from the standard __________ distribution because it has more area in the tails of the curve.
A t-distribution differs from the standard normal distribution because it has more __________ in the tails of the curve.
A t-distribution differs from the standard normal distribution because it has more area in the __________ of the curve.
A __________ is more appropriate for cases with more variability.
A t-distribution is more appropriate for cases with more __________.
The __________ has two sources of variation: from the sampling variability of x̄ and from the sampling variability of s.
The t-distribution has two sources of variation: from the __________ variability of x̄ and from the __________ variability of s.
With a __________ sample size, the t-distribution will approach the normal z-distribution.
With a larger __________, the t-distribution will approach the normal z-distribution.
With a larger sample size, the __________ will approach the normal z-distribution.
With a larger sample size, the t-distribution will approach the __________ z-distribution.
With a larger sample size, the t-distribution will approach the normal __________.
A __________ error occurs when the null hypothesis is true but we reject it.
A Type 1 error occurs when the null hypothesis is __________but we reject it.
A Type 1 error occurs when the null hypothesis is true but we __________ it.
A __________ error occurs when the null hypothesis is false but we fail to reject it.
A Type 2 error occurs when the null hypothesis is __________ but we fail to reject it.
A Type 2 error occurs when the null hypothesis is false but we __________ it.
The __________ of making a Type 1 error is our significance level α.
The probability of making a __________ error is our significance level α.
The probability of making a Type 1 error is our __________ α.
To reduce the risk of making a __________ error, we can decrease our significance level α.
To reduce the risk of making a Type 1 error, we can __________ our significance level α.
To reduce the risk of making a Type 1 error, we can decrease our __________ α.
To __________ the risk of making a Type 2 error, we can increase our sample size.
To reduce the risk of making a __________ error, we can increase our sample size.
To reduce the risk of making a Type 2 error, we can __________ our sample size.
To reduce the risk of making a Type 2 error, we can increase our __________.
